00040 //--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00041 // Entry point to the program. Initializes everything and goes into a message processing 
00042 // loop. Idle time is used to render the scene.
00043 //
00044 // See Game Coding Complete 2nd Edition - Chapter 5 - page 126
00045 // (this is _tWinMain in the book, renamed to GameCode2)
00046 //--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00047 
00048 INT WINAPI GameCode2(HINSTANCE hInstance,
00049                      HINSTANCE hPrevInstance,
00050                      LPTSTR    lpCmdLine,
00051                      int       nCmdShow)
00052 {
00053         // Set up checks for memory leaks.
00054         // Game Coding Complete reference - Chapter 12, page 446
00055         //
00056         int tmpDbgFlag = _CrtSetDbgFlag(_CRTDBG_REPORT_FLAG);
00057 
00058         // set this flag to keep memory blocks around
00059         //tmpDbgFlag |= _CRTDBG_DELAY_FREE_MEM_DF;                              // this flag will cause intermittent pauses in your game!
00060 
00061         // perform memory check for each alloc/dealloc
00062         //tmpDbgFlag |= _CRTDBG_CHECK_ALWAYS_DF;                                // remember this is VERY VERY SLOW!
00063 
00064         // always perform a leak check just before app exits.
00065         tmpDbgFlag |= _CRTDBG_LEAK_CHECK_DF;                                    
00066 
00067         _CrtSetDbgFlag(tmpDbgFlag);
00068 
00069 
00070     // Set the callback functions. These functions allow the sample framework to notify
00071     // the application about device changes, user input, and windows messages.  The 
00072     // callbacks are optional so you need only set callbacks for events you're interested 
00073     // in. However, if you don't handle the device reset/lost callbacks then the sample 
00074     // framework won't be able to reset your device since the application must first 
00075     // release all device resources before resetting.  Likewise, if you don't handle the 
00076     // device created/destroyed callbacks then the sample framework won't be able to 
00077     // recreate your device resources.
00078 
00079         DXUTSetCallbackDeviceCreated( GameCodeApp::OnCreateDevice );
00080         DXUTSetCallbackDeviceDestroyed( GameCodeApp::OnDestroyDevice );
00081         DXUTSetCallbackMsgProc( GameCodeApp::MsgProc );
00082     DXUTSetCallbackDeviceReset( GameCodeApp::OnResetDevice );
00083     DXUTSetCallbackDeviceLost( GameCodeApp::OnLostDevice );
00084         DXUTSetCallbackFrameRender( GameCodeApp::OnRender );
00085         DXUTSetCallbackFrameMove( GameCodeApp::OnUpdateGame );
00086 
00087     // Show the cursor and clip it when in full screen
00088     DXUTSetCursorSettings( true, true );
00089 
00090         // Perform application initialization
00091         if (!g_pApp->InitInstance (hInstance, lpCmdLine)) 
00092         {
00093                 return FALSE;
00094         }
00095 
00096 
00097     // Pass control to the sample framework for handling the message pump and 
00098     // dispatching render calls. The sample framework will call your FrameMove 
00099     // and FrameRender callback when there is idle time between handling window messages.
00100         DXUTMainLoop();
00101 
00102         DXUTSimpleShutdown();
00103         SAFE_DELETE(g_pApp->m_pDialogResourceManager);
00104 
00105         SAFE_DELETE(g_pApp->m_pGame);
00106 
00107         //_CRTDBG_LEAK_CHECK_DF is used at program initialization to force a 
00108         //   leak check just before program exit. This is important because
00109         //   some classes may dynamically allocate memory in globally constructed
00110         //   objects.
00111         //
00112         //_CrtDumpMemoryLeaks();                                        // Reports leaks to stderr
00113 
00114     return g_pApp->GetExitCode();       
00115 }

00118 //This is code that tests shared pointers.
00119 
00120 
00121 #include <boost\config.hpp>
00122 #include <boost\shared_ptr.hpp>
00123 
00124 using boost::shared_ptr;
00125 
00126 
00127 class IPrintable
00128 {
00129 public:
00130         virtual void VPrint()=0;
00131 };
00132 
00133 class CPrintable : public IPrintable
00134 {
00135         char *m_Name;
00136 public:
00137         CPrintable(char *name)   { m_Name = name; printf("create %s\n",m_Name); }
00138         virtual ~CPrintable()     { printf("delete %s\n",m_Name); }
00139         void VPrint()             { printf("print %s\n",m_Name); }
00140 };
00141 
00142 shared_ptr<CPrintable> CreateAnObject(char *name)
00143 {
00144         return shared_ptr<CPrintable>(new CPrintable(name));
00145 }
00146 
00147 void ProcessObject(shared_ptr<CPrintable> o)
00148 {
00149         printf("(print from a function) ");
00150         o->VPrint();
00151 }
00152 
00153 void TestSharedPointers(void)
00154 {
00155         shared_ptr<CPrintable> ptr1(new CPrintable("1"));       // create object 1
00156         shared_ptr<CPrintable> ptr2(new CPrintable("2"));       // create object 2
00157 
00158         ptr1 = ptr2;                                            // destroy object 1     
00159         ptr2 = CreateAnObject("3");                     // used as a return value
00160         ProcessObject(ptr1);                            // call a function
00161 
00162         // BAD USEAGE EXAMPLES....
00163         //
00164         CPrintable o1("bad");
00165         //ptr1 = &o1;      // Syntax error! It's on the stack....
00166         //
00167         CPrintable *o2 = new CPrintable("bad2");
00168         //ptr1 = o2;            // Syntax error! Use the next line to do this...
00169 
00170         ptr1 = shared_ptr<CPrintable>(o2);
00171 
00172         // You can even use shared_ptr on ints!
00173 
00174         shared_ptr<int> a(new int);
00175         shared_ptr<int> b(new int);
00176 
00177         *a = 5;
00178         *b = 6;
00179 
00180         const int *q = a.get();                         // use this for reading in MT code
00181 
00182         // this is especially cool - you can also use it in lists.
00183         std::list< shared_ptr<int> > intList;
00184         std::list< shared_ptr<IPrintable> > printableList;
00185         for (int i=0; i<100; ++i)
00186         {
00187                 intList.push_back(shared_ptr<int>(new int(rand())));
00188                 printableList.push_back(shared_ptr<IPrintable>(new CPrintable("list")));
00189         }
00190 
00191         int *z = new int;
00192         shared_ptr<int> bad1(z);
00193         shared_ptr<int> bad2(z);
00194 
00195 
00196         // No leaks!!!! Isn't that cool...
00197 }

00199 class CJelly;
00200 class CPeanutButter
00201 {
00202 public:
00203         shared_ptr<CJelly> m_pJelly;
00204         CPeanutButter(CJelly *pJelly) { m_pJelly.reset(pJelly); }
00205 };
00206 
00207 class CJelly
00208 {
00209 public:
00210         shared_ptr<CPeanutButter> m_pPeanutButter;
00211         CJelly();
00212 };
00213 
00214 CJelly::CJelly()
00215 {
00216         m_pPeanutButter.reset(new CPeanutButter(this));
00217 }

00220 void PleaseLeakMyMemory()
00221 {
00222         shared_ptr<CJelly> pJelly(new CJelly);
00223 }
